Not available

Hosts and five-time winners Brazil rightly go into the tournament as one of the favourites. With outstanding talents throughout the team and with an efficiency drilled by caoch Scolari, Brazil are capable of beating the best. The only worry may be that automatic qualification may mean the team will lack that competitive edge. However, it would be brave to bet against them especially with home advantage.
The twelfth man will be just enough to see Brazil edge past the others to win the World Cup on home soil.

So good they only named him once! Barcelona\'s Neymar is coming-of-age at the perfect time for this tournament. The hopes and prayers of his nation will be on his shoulders and he could achieve God-like status if he influences the team to a successful home World Cup.
Neymar

With some excellent players and a strategic manager, Croatia should be going into this tournament full of confidence. However, their qualifying campaign was lackluster and had they not been fortuitous enough to draw Iceland in the qualifiers they may well have been watching this tournament from a distance. With the players art their disposal, especially in midfield, they may cause problems even to the bigger teams. But they will need things to really click into place for them to progress beyond the second round.
Second round exit
The Real Madrid player is one of the best passers in world football and is the centre of all things that are good for Croatia. If he gets time and space he can cause real damage.
Luka Modrić

With recent managerial and playing-system changes, Mexico aren\'t arriving to the tournament in the settled state that would be preferred. They have at their disposal a number of talented players with plenty of pace and trickery. But given their tough group they will have to find something extra to progress very far.
Going home early
Although struggling to stake out a first team place at club Manchester United, Hernandez has skill and pace to burnf. He will need to be at his lethal best for Mexico to make any headlines.
Javier Hernández

One of the current forces of African football, Cameroon will be tricky opponents and will be unfazed by the high Brazilian temperatures. They have a wealth of pace, power and fitness but will need calm heads and strong leadership to make any waves.
Group exit
Samuel Eto\'o, the captain and leader, will need to inspire those around him to perform with the perfect balance of controlled agression to navigate a difficult group.
Samuel Eto\'o

The World Cup and Europen Cup holders go in to the tournament as one of favourites. The team largely remains the same, which is good from the point of view of stability, but perhaps a little bit worrying in terms of the ageing profile. Bayern Munich handed a blueprint to combat their short-passing style in their Champions League victory over Barcelona. Adding Brazil\'s comfotable federation cup final victory over the national team has lead some to conclude that the golden era for Spain is drawing to a close. This seems somewhat premature and Spain will be there right to the end.
Semi finalists
Delivers on the biggest occasions and will have to do so again if Spain are the conquer the other giants and lift the cup.
Andrés Iniesta

With a mouth-watering clash with Spain the pick of the early fixtures, this Dutch side has an interesting mix of youth and experience that will be very interesting to watch. Unfortunately, there is always the cloud of egos and infighting that often disrupts the Dutch in the big events. If they can avoid that, they can go far.
Quarter finals

It\'s hard to believe that Arjen Robben will only be 30 years old at this tournament. It seems like he has been playing forever. He contributes massively to Bayern winning the Champions League and will be massive for the Netherlands in Brazil.
Arjen Robben

Chile will feal resonably at home in Brazil and will play without any fear as expectation is not very high on them in a group with two of the giants of European football. Neither Spain nor The Netherlands will look forward to playing Chile and I can forsee them getting a result from one of those games.
Brave performances but ultimately a group stage exit.
The Juventus star is one of the most exciting talents in world football with lively link up play and good finishing on his resume.
Arturo Vidal

From Australia\'s point of view, this is a group of death. Their stars are passed their prime and their young talent is good but not superb. They will do well if they avoid embarrassment in one of the toughest groups of the tournament.
First flight home
The Crystal Palace captain is a gritty performer and will have to inspire this throughout the team for Australia not to go home blushing.
Mile Jedinak

Colombia looked like an assured team in qualifying and haven been given a group of which most other teams are jealous this could be the year for Colombia to finally fulfil their much touted ambitions. It will be interesting to see how their team fares against highly drilled European outfits (assuming they get that far) but they will definitley be a team to watch in Brazil.
Quarter finals with a chance to go further.
A sublime attacking talent, he could be one of the heroes of the cup.
Radamel Falcao
The Greeks boast a very mean defence and rigit organisation that makes them difficult for any team to beat. On the other side, they are lacking the flair of the serious contenders in this tournament.
Group stage exit
A top-class centre forward but will require his teammates to provide the service and this may be the problem.
Konstantinos Mitroglou

The highest ranked African team and definietely a team to watch in this tournament. They will fancy their chances of progression from this group and few teams will fancy meeting them beyond that stage. With an extremely fit and strong team, the grueling schedule of games will suit them better than most. Likely to cause an upset along the way and make a few headlines.
Quarter Finals
Man City\'s midfield engine is one of the finest players gracing the tournament and will help his team to some memorable results.
Yaya Toure

Japan have undoubted (if underrated) talent up front but lack the resiliance in defence that is needed to pose a serious threat of qualifying from this group. They are lightly to cause their opponents problems and show some flashed of brilliance but ultimately this is unlikely to be a trip for the Blue Samurai to remember for too long.
Moments of beautiful football but ultimately an early flight home.
Formerly one fo the finest players in the Budesliga, Kagawa gets very limited game time at Manchester United. Will feel he has a point to prove in Brazil.
Shinji Kagawa

With a fearsome attacking line, defenders will be having nightmares about going toe-to-toe with Uruguay. Luis Suarez is fast becoming one of the best strikers in the world and if his current form continues he looks capable of beating a team on his own. Uruguay will be looking to top the group and could definitely upset some big names in this tournament.
Quarter finals would seem very possible and I wouldn\'t bet against seeing them in the semis either.
He has everything to be one of the greats of this era. If he can keep his discipline in check he could be making a lot of headlines this summer.
Luis Suarez

Costa Rica boast a mean defence and their qualifying record is impressive. However, this is all against teams that could hardly claim to be in football\'s top tier. It will be interesting to see how Costa Rica will cope against stronger footballing nations and whether they can find a few goals to help them challenge for qualification from the group.
Group stage exit
A quality player who has all the talent but sometimes lacks consistency. Will need a huge tournament to avoid sitting at the bottom of the group after the first three games.
Bryan Ruiz

National expectation is low in England for this tournament which is possibly the first time ever in the modern era. A lot of the stars from their golden era are coming into their autumn years and under Roy Hodgson their qualification campaign was quite a conservative affair for the most part. Some recent performances have hinted towards a more expansive style of play but when the tournament pressure arrives it will be surprising if England don\'t focus more of their efforts on not conceding than on anything else.
Second round seems possible but getting much further would require some excellent performances and a slice of luck.
Having recently exploded onto the national team, this exciting player is capable of being the spark that England require.
Andros Townsend

Perennial overachievers in tournament football, you write Italy off at your peril. With an ability to get results that scarcely seem possible and often don\'t seem deserved, Italy could be there right to the end. However, on paper this side just doesn\'t look strong enough to compete. Pirlo is an undoubtedly fine player, but for your playmaker to be 35 years old in such hot conditions, it seems like Italy will struggle against top teams.
May scrape through the group but going home before the quarter final stage.
Pirlo can single-handedly dismantle teams, as he showed against England in their last tournament meeting. But has he the legs to play this packed schedule in such heat?
Andrea Pirlo

Impressive in qualifying and one of the top seeds of the tournament, the credentials of this Swiss team look good on paper. However, it remains to be seen how well they will cope when they are pitted against some of the bigger teams. Expect to see performances full of energy and organisation but their lack of creative flair may prevent them from making a huge impact at the cup.
Second round but no further.
The Bayern Muncih player combines a low centre of gravity with two-footed trickery that can be a handful for defenders.
Xerdan Shaqiri

Not hugely impressive in qualifying, particularly when away from home, there is little to suggest that Ecuador will be doing much more than making up the numbers at World Cup 2014. They have wingers with talent but there are many frailties throughout the team that are likely to get exposed on the biggest stage.
Early elimination
Undboutedly has the talent to shine at this tournament but could just as easily do nothing to be noticed.
Antonio Valencia

Having fought back from the brink of elimination in their qualfier against the Ukraine, France then landed the group that all the bottom seeds were dreaming of. Their team is full of star names and in coach Deschamps they have a man with a chance of keeping balance among the many egos in the squad.
A lot depends on the desire and harmony in the group, with anything from first round elimination to World Cup winners a possibility. Predicting quarter finals.
Already one of the world\'s best players, Ribery has taken his game to another level over the past couple of years and has become the complete player.
Franck Ribéry

Honduras would be happy to come home from this tournament with a win under their belts and would be ecstatic with anything more. The group is kind and they might not get a better opportunity for three World Cup points for some time to come.
May get that first win but still unlikely to qualify from the group.
Pacy left-back Emilio Izaguirre is a real attacking threat and will need to perform well for Honduras to get the goals and win their nation is dreaming of.
Emilio Izaguirre

The era of Maradonna\'s management of the Argentinian side was somewhat of a waste of the talents available but this time out Argentina have a better shot at making a real impact in the tournament. With a wealth of attacking talent and probably the world\'s best player, Argentina are real contenders to win the tournament in the home of their neighbours. The Brazilian public would rather see any other team win so Argentina can expect a hostile reception for the locals - will this distract or galvanise them?
Anything less than semi-finals would be a shock, but will need nerves of steel to win the tournament. Beaten semi-finalists.

Nominated the World\'s best player for the last four years and boasting a goal scoring record that is bordering on the obscene, it\'s going to take a lot for Messi not to have a huge influence in this tournament.
Lionel Messi

A solid team with some world-class players, Bosnia- Hertzegovina could make a name for themselves at their first World Cup. Capable of getting a result against any other team they will be one to watch.
Provided the occasion doesn\'t get to them, Bosnia-Herzegovina will get out of the group but the dream will end there.
Man City\'s Edin Dzeko scored 10 goals in the qualifying campaign and it will be no surprise if he knocks in a few more in Brazil.
Edin Džeko

Iran\'s form-guide won\'t frighten anyone in this tournament, including a 1-0 defeat at the hands of lowly Lebanon. They will be hoping to return from the tournament with their pride intact, which may even be a little to optimistic.
Second round seems possible but getting much further would require some excellent performances and a slice of luck.
The captain has been a mainstay of the team for a long time and will be hoping to bow out of international football with his head held high.
Javan Nekounam

There is no doubting that Nigeria have the pace and athleticism to cause their group opponents problems. Unfortunately they also have a note of turmoil in their organisation and performances can be inconsistent. Could cause an upset if everything lines up properly for them.
Their game with Boznia- Hertzegovena will be a fascinating one to watch and will likely decide which team progresses. I predict Nigeria to narrowly lose that game and bow out at the group stage.
Blossoming at Chelsea of late, Mickel possesses the ability to control a game and make it look easy.
John Obi Mikel

With a starting eleven as good as any in the tournament and a bench that is the envy of most of the world, Germany are incredibly strong contenders at this World Cup. Combining teachnical excellence with elite athleticism, it is going to take a team with doses of talent and organisation to stop the rampaging Germans from going all the way.
Beaten finalists.
His departure from Real Madrid over the summer was greeted by shock all around the footballing world, having been one of Madrid\'s star performers the previous season.
Mesut Özil

A team with many talented individuals that just seem to be lacking a bit of team-spirit. In Ronaldo they have probably the world\'s second-best player and he is capable of glossing over their dificiencies and dragging them to big results (as he notably did in the qualfier play-offs against Sweden).
Should cruise through the group but may struggle against more complete teams. Quarter finals.
Ronaldo will be keen to establish a case that he is a better player than certain other South American attackers.
Christiano Ronaldo

A strong midfield contrasts sharply with Ghana\'s options in defence and attack. They will play some nice football and may nick a goal or two but are unlikely to trouble the European big-boys in their group.
Group stage exit
Though a fading power at club level, Essien is still a huge player for the national team.
Michael Essien

For all the stubbornness and strong organisation in this US team, there is a conspicuous lack of world class players on the team sheet that will leave them fighting an uphill battle all the way. Expect guts and determination but ultimately little in the way of goals or success.
The Ghana game will be fun, the games against Germany and Portugal will be painful. Group exit.
Making a name for himself at Roma, this industious midfielder is the team\'s stand-out performer.
Michael Bradley

With a team-list that belies the diminutive size of their country, Belgium are a team that have a chance to go far in this tournament. Their lack of World Cup experience may play against them but few of the contenders for the title will relish a clash with this capable team.
Very capable of causing an upset or two. Quarter-finals.
Marshalls the back four and lends composure to all around him, an absolute class act.
Vincent Kompany
Having just scraped into the World Cup on away goals, Algeria are the rank outsiders of the tournament. However, with a young team and a strong work ethic, they will be difficult to beat.
Likely to earn plenty of pride but unlikely to progress from their group.
The Valencia player is the shining performer and Algeria will need him to be at his sparkling best to have a chance of progressing.
Sofiane Feghouli

The Russian team is a solid group with a few huge talents, most notably the dangerous Dzagoev. They find themselves in a group they should qualify from and the confidence they gain from that may be a springboard to something greater.
Second round seems likely, but with likely opponents of Germany or Portugal waiting, that will probably be as far as this team goes.
A lethal finisher, this is a really good chance for the CSKA man to shine under the biggest spotlight.
Alan Dzagoev

While they will rarely be outworked, this Korean team looks likely to be outplayed by their more talented group opponents. They won\'t make it easy but I don\'t think they\'ll cause any scares either.
Won\'t trouble Belgium or Russia. Group exit.
The Leverkusen attacker is the side\'s creative force and their leading light.
Son Heung Min
